In this research, a novel CoMn2O4 catalyst was prepared for the removal of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene. The catalyst showed better activity than that of MnO2 and Co3O4. The better activity of CoMn2O4 was attributed to the abundant concentration of Co2+, Mn3+, and lattice oxygen. Kinetic studies were carried out for the catalytic oxidation of three xylenes over the CoMn2O4 catalyst based on the Power-Low model, the Mars-van Krevelen model, the Eley-Rideal model, and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model. All the three reactions could be most accurately described by the Mars-van Krevelen model, which suggested that the isomers of xylene had very little effect on the mechanism of xylene oxidation over the CoMn2O4 catalyst. The activation energies of the oxidation processes of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene were 94.64 kJ/mol, 78.46 kJ/mol, and 57.13 kJ/mol, respectively. The proposed mechanism based on the Mars-van Krevelen model suggested that xylene molecules reacted with the Co3+ and Mn4+/Mn3+ on the CoMn2O4 catalyst and participated in the cycle of adsorption, redox, and desorption. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Kinetic study Catalyst mechanism Xylene Non-Nobel metal catalyst Catalytic oxidation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Xylenes are toxic volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emitted by industry. Xylene have three isomers, ortho-xylene (OX), meta-xylene (MX), and para-xylene (PX). Xylene emissions are considered to be harmful for the environment and the human body. Among the existing technologies for the removal of xylene, such as photocatalysis [1], catalytic oxidation [2,3,4], adsorption [5,6], and biological filtration [7], catalytic oxidation has the most potential for development owing to its advantages of high efficiency, low cost, and environmental friendliness. The key point of research on catalytic oxidation technology is to prepare a catalyst that can simultaneously improve the reaction degree of three kinds of xylene and reduce the reaction temperature. Previous reports indicated that noble metal catalysts displayed remarkable catalytic activity [8,9], but their high price limited their widespread usage. Therefore, researchers turned their attention to transition metal catalysts as inexpensive and earth-abundant alternatives to precious metal catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. Among, Mn-based and cobalt catalysts have become the focus of research [10,11,12]. The oxides of cobalt stood out for their large number of oxygen vacancies and capability of oxygen storage. The abundant concentration of Co3+ benefited the activation of reactive oxygen, resulting in a more compact redox cycle which increased the mobility of oxygen species [13,14]. Manganese oxides were widely used in catalysts due to their multivariable valence state (Mn4+, Mn3+, Mn2+). According to the Mars-van Krevelen model, large amounts of Mn4+ were advantageous for raising the ratio of lattice oxygen/adsorbed oxygen, and lattice oxygen had a positive role in enhancing catalytic activity [15,16]. Many recent studies have discovered that the catalytic performance of binary metal mixtures is superior to that of single metal oxides. For example, it has been reported by Chen et al. [17] that the combination of manganese and cerium could enhance the conversion of o-xylene compared to pure MnO2 and CeO2 by promoting the occurrence of crystal defects and increasing oxygen vacancies. Meanwhile, the 3Mn1Ce sample improved the ratio of surface lattice oxygen to adsorbed oxygen, which was considered to be conducive to compliance with the Mars-van Krevelen model. Li et al. [18] found that the temperature for the complete combustion of toluene over CoMnOx catalyst was 30°C higher than Mn3O4 and Co3O4. A low-reducibility temperature and abundant surface oxygen vacancies might be the main factors. The formation of Co-Mn solid solution enhanced the electron transfer between cobalt and manganese ions, which promoted the redox ability. [19] Co-Mn binary mixtures exhibited great promise in the catalytic oxidation of toluene. However, the application in the oxidation of xylene has yet to be further developed. The catalytic activity can be better improved by the synergistic effect of two metals. In addition, the kinetic model is also a factor to be considered in catalytic oxidation [20]. A clear reaction mechanism provides a better prediction for the reaction rate. Although there are many studies on catalytic oxidation of xylenes in the literature, most are restricted to a certain xylene isomer. In fact,·the three isomers of xylene often appear as mixtures in industry and are difficult to distinguish. Thus, in this work, a CoMn2O4 catalyst was prepared for the removal of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene, respectively. The catalyst exhibited good catalytic activities under three conditions, and the reason was also explored. The kinetic studies of three xylenes over the CoMn2O4 catalyst were carried out using the Power-Low model and mechanism models. Meanwhile, the possible reaction mechanism was predicted following the kinetic model. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials MnO2 was provided by Minsizhuang technology Company, Hunan; Co3O4 (Luoen Reagent, 99.90%), o-xylene, m-xylene, p-xylene and Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Luoen Reagent Company, AR); Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent, AR). 2.2 Catalyst preparation The CoMn2O4 catalyst was synthesized via the Gel method. Co(NO3)2·6H2O (10 mmol) and Mn(CH3COO)2·4H2O (20 mmol) were dissolved in 15 mL absolute ethanol, and then the solution was heated at 60°C in a magnetic stirring oil bath to form a purple-red gelatinous precursor. Solid oxalic acid (36 mmol) was dissolved in 150 mL deionized water, and the solution was poured into the precursor and vigorously stirred at 60°C for 30 min. The resulting suspension was filtered out and washed three times with deionized water and absolute ethanol. Then, the product was dried at 60°C for 8 h. The CoMn2O4 sample was finally obtained after calcination at 350°C for 3 h. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a Bruker D8-Focus instrument with a monochromatic Cu Kα source operated at 40 kV and 40 mA, and the 2θ range was from 15° to 75°. TEM images were obtained on a JEM-F200 (JEOL, Japan), and SEM images were taken in an Apreo S LoVac (FEI, America) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV. Nitrogen physisorption was performed with an Autosorb-IQ2-MP (USA), and the surface area and pore volume of the samples were measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis. Before N2 physisorption, the catalysts were degassed at 300°C for 4 hours. K-Alpha+ was used to test X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) images with Mg Kα as the excitation source. H2-Temperature programmed reduction(H2-TPR), the catalysts were degassed at 200°C for 1 h under an Ar atmosphere. The purge gas was switched to a 10 vol.% H2/Ar mixture with a flow rate of 30 mL/min as the temperature dropped to 50°C. The signal was detected by a TCD detector. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic oxidation reactions of xylenes occurred on a fixed bed quartz reactor (d=6 mm, l=645 mm) to evaluate catalytic performance with 100 mg of catalyst (40-60 mesh). The reactant feed was composed of 1000 ppm o-xylene, and air passed through the catalyst layer with a flow rate of 100 mL/min, giving a weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 60000 mL/g/h. A gas chromatograph equipped with FID was used to detect the concentration of xylene. The xylene conversion (X) was calculated by the following formula: (1) X ( % ) = c i n − c o u t c i n where c i n and c o u t are the inlet and outlet concentrations of xylene, respectively. 3 Result 3.1 Catalyst characterization 3.1.1 XRD analysis The CoMn2O4 catalyst was compared with Co3O4 and MnO2. The XRD results of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The peaks of both MnO2 and Co3O4 samples belong to pure MnO2 (JCPDS 44-0141) and Co3O4 (JCPDS 74-1657), respectively. The diffraction peaks of CoMn2O4 at 2θ = 31.2°, 33.8°, 36.1°, 44.1°, 58°, and 65.18° should be assigned to CoMn2O4 (JCPDS No. 77-0471) phase [21]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ=18.2°, 29.3°, and 60.9° could be assigned to (CoMn)(CoMn)2O4 (JCPDS No. 18-0408) [22]. No peaks related to MnO2, Mn2O3, CoO, or Co3O4 were detected, indicating that these phases dispersed homogeneously on the catalyst surface or the particles were too small to detect. Manganese and cobalt were successful in building the mainly CoMn2O4 crystal phase and a few (CoMn)(CoMn)2O4 structures [23]. 3.1.2 Analyses of morphological and microstructural SEM and TEM images of CoMn2O4 are shown in Fig. 2 . (a) and (b), respectively. The morphology of CoMn2O4 was composed of bulk particles with lamellar structures resulting in an unsmooth surface, which could increase the specific surface area and facilitate the contact between xylene molecules and catalyst. Abundant lattice fringes could be seen in Fig. 2. (b), “d=0.25 nm” was related to the (311) crystal plane of CoMn2O4 [24] and “d=0.475 nm” was the (111) crystal plane of (CoMn)(CoMn)2O4 [22]. As shown in Fig. 2. (c), the reduced adsorption properties went against the catalytic reaction because the surface of Co3O4 was smooth and dense with almost no holes. The SEM image of MnO2 is shown in Fig. 2. (d). The rod-shaped morphology was conducive to the formation of slit pore structures, revealing the reason for the large specific surface area. 3.1.3 Analyses of surface area The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms are exhibited in Fig. 3 , the BET surface area and pore-size distributions are summarized in Table 1 . CoMn2O4 and MnO2 exhibited the isotherms of type Ⅳ with a type H3 hysteresis loop and H4 hysteresis loop, respectively. It can be inferred that the MnO2 sample possessed slit pores with lamellar buildups and the CoMn2O4 showed aggregates consisting of laminar structures. The pore diameters were in the range of 8-10 nm, indicating that the samples had the mesoporous structure. Co3O4 presented the isotherm of type Ⅲ, which illustrated the structure of intergranular macroporous and non-porous. These results were in line with the SEM and TEM observations. MnO2 showed the largest surface area (175.75 m2/g), followed by CoMn2O4 (81.89 m2/g) and Co3O4 (0.65 m2/g). The surface area of CoMn2O4 was less than that of MnO2, which might be ascribed to the occurrence of agglomeration. The high area of the BET surface has been proven to be helpful for improving the catalytic activity. However, CoMn2O4 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity, indicating that the BET-specific surface was not the key factor impacting the catalytic performance of the samples in this research. 3.1.4 XPS and H2-TPR analysis The surface chemical states of the Mn, Co, and O elements of the three catalysts were tested by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 4 . (a), Mn2p spectrum is fitted to a pair of spin-orbit peaks (Mn 2p1/2 and Mn2p3/2). The peaks at 640.6 eV, 651.8eV belong to Mn2+, 642.0eV, 653.2eV belong to Mn3+, and 643.4eV, 654.7eV belong to Mn4+. [25,26]. The information on the surface chemical state is listed in Table 1. Regarding the MnO2 catalyst, the content of Mn4+ accounted for more than half of the total, Mn3+ accounted for 24.9%, and only a tiny portion of Mn2+ existed. For the CoMn2O4 catalyst, Mn3+ was the dominant valence state (51.7%), accompanied by 37.2% of Mn4+ and 11.1% of Mn2+, indicating that the doping of cobalt was beneficial to the formation of Mn3+. The oxygen vacancies generated due to the redox reaction: Mn4+—O2−—Mn4+ → Mn3+—□—Mn3+ + O2. Therefore, more Mn3+ concentration was considered to be the presence of more oxygen vacancies [27]. Meanwhile, it has been reported that higher Mn3+/Mn4+ could lower the reduction temperature. [28] The Co 2p spectra is displayed in Fig. 4. (b). Co2p is fitted to a pair of spin-orbit peaks: Co 2p1/2 (796.5 eV) and Co2p3/2 (781.3 eV). The peaks at about 787.4eV and 803.5eV are satellite shake-ups of the Co2+ components. [29,30] Intense satellite peaks of Co2+ appeared in the spectrum of CoMn2O4, which were weakly reflected in the spectrum of Co3O4, demonstrating the formation of more low valence cobalt (Co2+) in the CoMn2O4 catalyst. The presence of Co2+ could be an indication of the generation of oxygen vacancies in the catalyst which was beneficial for promoting catalytic activity. As shown in Fig. 4. (c), the O 1s spectrum can be divided into three peaks. The peaks centered at 529.6 eV and 531.5 eV, 532.9 eV are identified as surface lattice oxygen(Olatt), absorbed oxygen species(Oads), and surface OH species (OOH) [31]. Olatt species were the major oxygen species in the CoMn2O4 sample. The formation of the Co-Mn solid solution led to lattice defects, exposing more active sites and increasing the concentration of lattice oxygen [32]. The redox reaction between lattice oxygen and xylene molecules was the key step based on the Mars-van Krevelen model, which was verified in the later section [15]. The increased content of lattice oxygen contributed to the catalytic activity of the sample. MnO2 possessed a comparable quantity of Oads and Olatt species. Oads species were considered to be related to the deep oxidation of VOCs. The balance of two oxygen species was accountable for the high activity of MnO2. Fig. 4. (d) displays the H2-TPR profile of the three samples. For the MnO2 sample, the peak centered at 288°C could be attributed to the reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+, and the second peak centered at 372°C could be assigned to the reduction of Mn3+ to Mn2+ [33]. The two peaks of Co3O4 were ascribed to the reduction process of Co3O4→CoO→Co0 [22]. Three strong reduction peaks at 203°C, 315°C, and 444°C could be observed in the pattern of CoMn2O4. Compared with pure Co3O4, the first reduction peak moved to a lower temperature. The second one might be related to the reduction of Mn3+/Mn4+ to Mn2+, which shifted to a lower temperature than the temperature of MnO2. The third H2 consumption peak at 444°C corresponded to the reduction of CoO to Co0 [34,35]. The peaks at 203°C and 315°C moved towards lower temperatures, indicating that the reducibility of the composite metal oxide materials had been improved due to the formation of the Co-Mn solid solution and the interaction between cobalt and manganese. A lower reduction temperature was beneficial for improving catalytic activity [36]. The reduction temperature of the catalysts was in the order of CoMn2O4 < MnO2 < Co3O4, which was in good agreement with the catalytic oxidation capability. 3.2 Kinetic study 3.2.1 Influence of mass transfer limitation The kinetic parameters are obtained based on excluding the influence of external and internal diffusion. It is assumed that the diffusion rate is quick enough that the negative effect on the reaction rate can be ignored. Fig. 5 . (a) shows the plots of the o-xylene conversion with different liquid flow rates from 25 mL/min to 150 mL/min. When the flow rate was less than 50 mL/min, the conversion of o-xylene rose with sequential increments in flow rate, implying that the reaction rate was controlled by external diffusion. The conversion of o-xylene tended to be stable when the flow rate was above 50 mL/min, and external diffusion effect could be considered to have been eliminated. Consequently, a flow rate of 100 mL/min was used as the condition for the next experiment. Intrinsic diffusion excluding experiments were carried out on catalysts weighing 100 mg with a volumetric content of 1000 ppm o-xylene with dry air at a constant flow rate of 100 mL/min. The effect of catalyst particle size on the o-xylene conversion was investigated and depicted in Fig. 5(b). It can be shown that the o-xylene conversion was unaffected by the size of the catalyst particle. As a result, it is acceptable to assume that the impact of internal diffusion might be neglected at 40-60 mesh catalyst particles. 3.2.2 Catalytic performance Fig. 6 . shows the catalytic performance of the aforementioned catalysts in the oxidation of o-xylene(a), m-xylene(b), and p-xylene(c). It is clear that the CoMn2O4 performed better than the MnO2 and Co3O4, giving 90% conversion at 277, 252, and 248°C for the oxidation of o-, m- and p-xylene, indicating that the Co-Mn phase significantly improved the catalytic oxidation of xylenes. The order of activity should be CoMn2O4 > MnO2 > Co3O4. The temperature required for the complete oxidation of o-xylene was the highest among the three xylenes. The stability of the CoMn2O4 catalyst for the oxidation of o-xylene was tested at 290°C with a space velocity of 60000 mL g−1 h−1. As shown in Fig. 6. (d), no substantial decrease in the conversion was observed under the reaction conditions, indicating that the catalyst possessed good stability. 3.3 Catalytic oxidation kinetics of xylene VOCs catalytic oxidation is often considered to follow the Power-Low model and mechanism models. On the basis of reasonable assumptions, several kinetic models have been derived, such as the Mars-van Krevelen model, the Eley-Rideal model, and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model. The models mentioned above were used to fit the experimental data of xylene oxidation over the CoMn2O4 catalyst. 3.3.1 Power-Low model The reaction rate expression of the Power-Low (P-L) model is independent of the reaction mechanism but is dependent on the rate constant and the concentration of the reactant. Equation 2 is the expression of the Power-Law model. (2) − r A = k C A m C O 2 n where - r A is the oxidation rate of xylene, C A and C O 2 are the concentrations of xylene and O2, respectively. m and n are the kinetic orders of xylene and oxygen, respectively. k is the reaction rate constant. Equation 2 can be simplified to equation 3 due to excessive oxygen concentration. (3) − r A = k ′ C A m (4) l n ( − r A ) = l n k ′ + m l n C A Equation 4 was applied to analyze the kinetic parameters of the catalytic oxidation of the three kinds of xylene. The apparent reaction rate constant (k') and activation energy follow the Arrhenius equation. The Arrhenius equation is written as follows: (5) k ′ = k 0 ′ e − E A R T where EA is the reaction activation energy, k 0 ′ is the pre-exponential factor, R is the gas constant, and T is the reaction temperature. Fig. 7 . displays the linear fitting of the experimental data of o-, m-, and p-xylene, and Arrhenius plots obtained based on the P-L model. The kinetic parameters are listed in Table 2 . The P-L model gave a good fit to the Arrhenius equation for the catalytic oxidation of o-xylene, but the linear correlation coefficients of m-xylene (0.87) and p-xylene (0.84) were relatively low compared to o-xylene. Thus, it can be suggested that the P-L model was a good depiction of the catalytic oxidation process of o-xylene, and the behavior of m-xylene and p-xylene could only be described by the P-L model to a certain extent. 3.3.2 Mars-van Krevelen model It is generally accepted that the catalytic oxidation mechanism of VOCs over metal oxide catalysts proceeds via the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) model [31]. The MvK mechanism speculates that xylenes are involved in two steps. In the first step, xylene molecules in the gas phase are adsorbed onto the surface of the catalysts and oxidized by the lattice oxygen [37]. During the second step, the reduced catalysts are oxidized by the oxygen species in the gas phase to form new active sites, and the process repeats itself. The oxidation reaction on the catalyst surface is thought to be the rate-determining step [38]. (6) C 8 H 10 + 10.5 O 2 → Cat 8 CO 2 + 5 H 2 O (7) r A = − d c A d t = k A c A θ (8) r O 2 = − d c O 2 d t = k O 2 c O 2 ( 1 − θ ) where k A is the consumption reaction (reduction reaction) rate constant of xylene. k O 2 is the consumption reaction (oxidation reaction) rate constant of O2. θ is the coverage of adsorbed molecules on the catalyst surface. According to the steady state approximation rule, there should be a dynamic equilibrium between the rate of oxidation and reduction reaction steps. According to the stoichiometric relation, r A =10.5 r O 2 , equation 7 can be further simplified as: (9) 1 − r A = 10.5 k O 2 c O 2 + 1 k A c A Taking 1 − r A as the ordinate and 1 c A as the abscissa to fit the data points, k A and k O 2 could be calculated. Fig. 8 . illustrates the fitting information of the three xylenes under the MvK model and the Arrhenius statement. The kinetic parameters simulated by the MvK model obtained from Fig. 8. are listed in Table 3 . There is a strong correlation (0.98) between the MvK model and the catalytic oxidation of o-xylene. The linear correlation values for m-xylene and p-xylene are around 0.94. Table 3 shows the kinetic parameters obtained by the MvK model. Interestingly, the activation energy values obtained by the MvK model and P-L model followed the same trend: o-xylene > m-xylene > p-xylene, which was consistent with the conclusion obtained in the catalyst activity performance test section that the temperature required for the complete oxidation of three xylenes followed the order of o-xylene > m-xylene > p-xylene. 3.3.3 Eley-Rideal model The Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism can be divided into two cases: (1) VOC molecules are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and then react with O2 molecules in the gas phase, and (2) VOC molecules in the gas phase react with the O2 molecules adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies of the catalyst. The speculation process of the reaction rate expression under the E-R model is as follows: (10) A + θ ⇔ K A A θ (11) A θ + O 2 → k CO 2 + H 2 O + θ where K A is the adsorption equilibrium constant of xylene and k is the reaction rate constant. (12) − r A = k K A c A c O 2 1 + K A c A It can be assumed that it remained constant due to the high oxygen concentration. Thus, k ′ = kc O 2 (13) − 1 r A = 1 k ′ K A c A + 1 k ′ For the reaction of VOC adsorption, (14) l n K A = l n K A 0 + q R T where q is the value of adsorption heat. Taking 1 − r A as the ordinate and 1 c A as the abscissa to fit the data points, the linearized form processed by the E-R model is shown in Fig 9 . (a). The result of the oxidation and reduction process of the three xylenes conformed to the Arrhenius equation, in which k showed an increasing trend with increasing temperature. The three xylenes showed the same characteristics in the fit of the two processes. The Arrhenius equation of the reaction process of the three xylenes gave the goodness of fit, among which the o-xylene reaction showed the highest (0.98). However, the Arrhenius equation of the adsorption process of the three xylenes provided a low degree of fit. In general, the catalytic oxidation of three types of xylenes on the CoMn2O4 sample cannot be described by the E-R model. 3.3.4 Langmuir-Hinshelwood model According to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) model, the description of the mechanism is as follows: (15) A + θ ⇔ K A A θ (16) O 2 + θ ⇔ K O 2 2 O θ (17) A θ + O θ ⇔ k CO 2 + H 2 O + 2 θ where A θ and O θ are the binding of the xylene and O2 molecules to the active sites. (b) and the data is listed in Table 4 . The linear fitting of m-xylene and p-xylene are displayed in Tables S1 and S2. Based on the facts gained above, we could conclude that the L-H model provided a good match to the three kinds of xylenes. However, it is worth noting that negative values for some of the kinetic parameters were found, such as the reaction rate constant and adsorption rate constant, which were manifestly implausible. As a consequence, it might be claimed that the catalytic oxidation of three xylenes on the CoMn2O4 sample could not be reflected by the L-H model. 3.4 Model checking As discussed above, the reaction processes of all the xylenes confirmed the Mars-van Krevelen model. Fig. 9. (c) shows the values calculated by the MvK model and the experimental data. The fitting coefficients were all above 0.98. These results suggested that the catalytic reaction rate equations of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene on the CoMn2O4 catalyst followed the MvK mechanism. The reaction kinetics of three xylenes over the CoMn2O4 catalyst were consistent. Therefore, the catalytic oxidation mechanism of xylene mixtures can be inferred from that of pure xylene. 3.5 Reaction mechanism According to the MvK model, the lattice oxygen has an important influence on the oxidation activity. Abundant Mn3+ and Co2+ content in CoMn2O4 catalyst made it easier for oxygen species to release from the crystal lattice and then generate more oxygen vacancies [39]. Meanwhile, Mn4+ and Co3+ were reported to be involved in the oxidation of formaldehyde as active sites [40]. The catalytic oxidation process of xylene over the CoMn2O4 catalyst was divided into two steps as shown in Fig. 10 . Firstly, xylene molecules were adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and oxidized by lattice oxygen present in the oxidized active sites to partial oxidation species. Mn4+/Mn3+ and Co3+ as oxidized active sites were reduced to Mn2+, and Co2+, then the oxygen vacancies formed [33]. Secondly, the partial oxidation species were further oxidized to CO2 and H2O by the active oxygen species. The gas oxygen molecules adsorbed onto the reduction sites on the catalyst surface and converted to lattice oxygen to fill the oxygen vacancies. The reduction sites were oxidized to oxidation active sites, and the cycle was repeated. During this cycle, the enhancement of oxygen mobility benefited the catalytic activity. Based on this, the activity of this catalyst can be improved by introducing multivalent metals as active carriers. The carriers provide more active sites and the increased ability of lattice oxygen to fill oxygen vacancies speeds the redox cycle, resulting in increased oxygen mobility [41,42]. Furthermore, the linkage between the new ions and other ions will be established to transfer electrons, and the entire redox state is energized [43]. 4 Conclusion In this work, a novel CoMn2O4 catalyst was successfully prepared by the Gel method. XRD results showed that the solid solution phases were formed between cobalt and manganese. This catalyst showed good stability and the highest catalytic performance (T90% = 277, 251, and 248°C for o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene, respectively) compared to MnO2 or Co3O4 catalysts. The high activity was attributed to the abundant concentration of Co2+, Mn3+, and lattice oxygen species on the catalyst surface, and lower reduction temperature than MnO2 and Co3O4. From the kinetic studies, the oxidation reactions of three xylenes over the CoMn2O4 catalyst could be accurately described by the Mars-van Krevelen model with the linear correlation coefficients around 0.97, which were much higher than the Power-Low model, the Eley-Rideal model, and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model. The isomers were shown to have little effect on this reaction mechanism. This conclusion has never been proven in the past and it will provide a reference for future research on the catalytic oxidation mechanism of xylene isomers. The activation energies of the oxidation processes of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene were 94.64 kJ/mol, 78.46 kJ/mol, and 57.13 kJ/mol, respectively. Analysis of the mechanism implied that xylene molecules were involved in a cycle of adsorption, redox, and desorption. The oxygen mobility was improved by the redox reaction of cobalt and manganese ions in this cycle. coredata.dc:description: In this research, a novel CoMn2O4 catalyst was prepared for the removal of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene. The catalyst showed better activity than that of MnO2 and Co3O4. The better activity of CoMn2O4 was attributed to the abundant concentration of Co2+, Mn3+, and lattice oxygen. Kinetic studies were carried out for the catalytic oxidation of three xylenes over the CoMn2O4 catalyst based on the Power-Low model, the Mars-van Krevelen model, the Eley-Rideal model, and the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model. All the three reactions could be most accurately described by the Mars-van Krevelen model, which suggested that the isomers of xylene had very little effect on the mechanism of xylene oxidation over the CoMn2O4 catalyst. The activation energies of the oxidation processes of o-xylene, m-xylene, and p-xylene were 94.64 kJ/mol, 78.46 kJ/mol, and 57.13 kJ/mol, respectively. The proposed mechanism based on the Mars-van Krevelen model suggested that xylene molecules reacted with the Co3+ and Mn4+/Mn3+ on the CoMn2O4 catalyst and participated in the cycle of adsorption, redox, and desorption.
coredata.dc:title: Novel CoMn2O4 as a highly efficient catalyst for the oxidation of o-, m-, p-xylene: Preparation and kinetic study
